cyclone.name: IAN
cyclone.current_location: about 315 mi (510 km) SE of Kingston, Jamaica
cyclone.trajectory: Forecast to curve northwest late Sunday, cross western Cuba Monday night, then move north-northwest across the eastern Gulf toward the Florida Peninsula and the southeast U.S. coastline
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: western Cuba (first landfall) – later a second landfall is possible along Florida’s west coast

weather_observation.watch_coast: Hurricane Watch – Cayman Islands; Tropical Storm Watch – Jamaica (no U.S. coast under watch yet)
weather_observation.warning_coast: None along U.S. coast in this advisory
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Entire Florida Peninsula, Florida Keys, northeastern Gulf Coast, southeast Georgia and the Carolinas are within the 5-day cone
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds (35-45 kt with higher gusts) possible late Wednesday night through Thursday
weather_observation.storm_surge: 2–4 ft surge possible along the northeast Florida coast including the St. Johns River mouth if Ian emerges over the Atlantic near the Georgia/Florida border
weather_observation.rainfall: 4–6 in. of rainfall possible Thursday–Friday, leading to localized flash flooding
weather_observation.other_hazards: High surf, dangerous rip currents and a low-end tornado threat in feeder bands
